citation.article-title: Paenibacillus konsidensis sp. nov., isolated from a patient.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Paenibacillus konsidensis sp. nov.
Paenibacillus konsidensis [kon.si.den′sis. N.L. masc. adj. konsidensis pertaining to KONSID, arbitrary adjective formed from the Korean Network for Studies of Infectious Diseases (KONSID)].
Cells are aerobic, Gram-positive, facultatively anaerobic rods (0.5 μm wide and 2.0–3.5 μm long).
Ellipsoidal endospores are formed at terminal or subterminal positions.
Grows optimally on blood agar at 37 °C and pH 7.0 (range 30–42 °C and pH 5.2−8.0); growth is observed at 2 % but not at 5 % NaCl.

Utilizes l-arabinose, ribose, d-xylose, methyl β-d-xyloside, galactose, glucose, fructose, mannose, rhamnose, methyl α-d-glucoside, N-acetylglucosamine, amygdalin, arbutin, aesculin, salicin, cellobiose, maltose, lactose, melibiose, sucrose, trehalose, raffinose, starch, glycogen, gentiobiose, turanose and gluconate as sole carbon and energy source (API 50 CH system), but not glycerol, erythritol, d-arabinose, l-xylose, adonitol, sorbose, dulcitol, inositol, mannitol, sorbitol, methyl α-d-mannoside, inulin, melezitose, xylitol, d-xylose, d-tagatose, d-fucose, l-fucose, d-arabitol, l-arabitol or 2-ketogluconate.

Positive for reduction of nitrate to nitrite, β-glucosidase, β-galactosidase and N-acetylglucosamine, and assimilation of maltose (API 20NE system), but negative for production of indole, production of acid from d-glucose, arginine dihydrolase, urease, hydrolysis of aesculin and gelatin and assimilation of d-glucose, d-arabinose, d-mannose, d-mannitol, gluconate, caprate, adipate, malate, citrate and phenylacetate.
Starch and Tween 80 are hydrolysed but casein is not.
Major fatty acids are anteiso-C15 : 0 (43.8 %), C16 : 0 (10.4 %), iso-C16 : 0 (10.3 %), iso-C15 : 0 (9.2 %) and anteiso-C17 : 0 (8.3 %).
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 51.3 mol%.
The type strain, LBYT (=ABB-ID-KSY9T=KCTC 13165T=JCM 14798T), was isolated from the blood of a febrile patient.
